newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - April 22.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - April 22.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The government, the Moro National Liberation Front and the United Nations will sign an agreement for the development of basic services and job creation for former Moslem rebels and their families (MANILA BULLETIN)

- Former senator and Armed forces chief of staff Rodolfo Biazon says the appointments of former military officers to civilian posts is a potent temptation for anyone to control the state. (PHILIPPINE DAILY INQUIRER)

- The government posts a deficit of only 648 million pesos in the first three months of this year instead of the programmed 4.97 billion pesos due to declining interest rates and tight expenditure programme, the finance department says. (BUSINESS JOURNAL)
- Oil refiner Petron Corp expects to dominate the local oil market despite the entry of new players under the fully deregulated oil industry, officials say. (TODAY)

- House leaders say they have decided to lower the proposed tax rates on dividends and sale of property to pacify the business sector and set the final individual tax exemption of 146,000 pesos for a household of six. (BUSINESSWORLD)

- The National Steel Corp (NSC) has asked the government to raise the tariff on imported tin plates to the original 10 percent from the present three percent to give the NSC enough time to regain its market share. (BUSINESS BULLETIN)
